actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:30 a.m. on June 22, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Grothman moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 4004.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Smith (MO) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 4004 — "To approve and implement the Agreement between the American Institute in Taiwan and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States regarding Trade between the United States of America and Taiwan, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3797.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Smith (MO) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3797 — "To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide an alternative manner of furnishing certain health insurance coverage statements to individuals."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 3801.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Smith (MO) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 3801 — "To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to streamline and improve the employer reporting process relating to health insurance coverage and to protect dependent privacy."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
Mr. Smith (MO) asked unanimous consent that when the House adjourns today, it adjourn to meet at 10:30 a.m. on June 22. Agreed to without objection.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 521, Mr. Schiff of California presented himself in the well of the House for the purpose of administration of censure by the Speaker of the House.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 213
actions-list.actionItem: 209, 6 Present (Roll no. 283).
Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 521 — "Censuring Adam Schiff, Representative of the 30th Congressional District of California."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 220
On motion to recommit Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 209

actions-list.actionItem: The previous question on the motion to recommit was ordered pursuant to clause 2(b) of rule XIX.
Mr. Doggett moved to recommit to the Committee on Ways and Means.
The House adopted the amendments en gross as agreed to by the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 3799.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Roy amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: 228
On agreeing to the Molinaro amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: 281
On agreeing to the Hayes amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 211

actions-list.actionItem: The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 3799 — "To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for health reimbursement arrangements integrated with individual health insurance coverage."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to the amendments and passage of H.R. 3799, if ordered, and agreeing to H. Res. 521, which had all been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The Chair directed the Clerk to notify the Senate of the action of the House.
On motion to refer the bill and the accompanying veto message to the Committee on Education and the Workforce. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to refer the bill and accompanying veto message to the Committee on Education and the Workforce.

actions-list.header: On passage, the objections of the President to the contrary notwithstanding Failed by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 221

actions-list.actionItem: The previous question was ordered without objection.

Pursuant to a previous order of the House of June 7, 2023 the unfinished business is the further consideration of the veto message of the President on H.J. Res. 45. The House proceeded with one hour of debate on the objections of the President to the contrary notwithstanding.
The Chair laid before the House the veto message from the President.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 3799 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Ms. Foxx moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Roy amendment No. 3, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced ayes had prevailed. Mr. Doggett demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 524, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Roy amendment No. 3.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Roy,  numbered 3 printed in Part D of House Report 118-115 to express the sense of Congress that healthcare freedom is the future of healthcare.

At the conclusion of debate on the Molinaro amendment No. 2, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Doggett demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 524, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Molinaro amendment No. 2.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Molinaro,  numbered 2 printed in Part D of House Report 118-115 to ensure that the Secretary notifies employers of the availability of tax-advantaged flexible health insurance benefits, with an official focus on small businesses, particularly in rural areas.

At conclusion of debate on the Hayes amendment No. 1, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mrs. Hayes demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 524, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hayes amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Hayes,  numbered 1 printed in Part D of House Report 118-115 to delay implementation of H.R. 3799 until the Secretary of Labor certifies that legislation would not result in higher premium rates for older workers.
The Committee of the Whole proceeded with eighty minutes of general debate on H.R. 3799.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Eric A. "Rick" Crawford to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 524 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 3564, H.R. 3799 and H. Res. 461. The resolution provides for consideration of H.R. 3564 under a structured rule with one hour of general debate; H.R. 3799 under a structured rule with eighty minutes of general debate; and H. Res. 461, under a closed rule with one hour of general debate. The resolution provides for a motion to recommit on H.R. 3564 and H.R. 3799.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 524. H.R. 3799 — "To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for health reimbursement arrangements integrated with individual health insurance coverage."

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 521, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Raskin demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proccedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 521.

actions-list.header: On motion to table the measure Failed by recorded vote: 208

actions-list.actionItem: Ms. Clark (MA) moved to table the measure.
Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 521 — "Censuring Adam Schiff, Representative of the 30th Congressional District of California."

actions-list.header: QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE
actions-list.actionItem: Mrs. Luna rose to a question of the privileges of the House and offered the resolution. The Chair directed the Clerk to report the resolution. Upon examination of the resolution, the Chair determined that the resolution did constitute a question of the privileges of the House.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 215
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 215

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 524 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3564) to cancel recent changes made by the Federal Housing Finance Agency to the up-front loan level pricing adjustments charged by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for guarantee of single-family mortgages, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3799) to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for health reimbursement arrangements integrated with individual health insurance coverage; and providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 461) condemning the use of elementary and secondary school facilities to provide shelter for aliens who are not admitted to the United States."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 524, and agreeing to the resolution, if ordered, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of June 21.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 524, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 524.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 524 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3564) to cancel recent changes made by the Federal Housing Finance Agency to the up-front loan level pricing adjustments charged by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for guarantee of single-family mortgages, and for other purposes; providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 3799) to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide for health reimbursement arrangements integrated with individual health insurance coverage; and providing for consideration of the resolution (H. Res. 461) condemning the use of elementary and secondary school facilities to provide shelter for aliens who are not admitted to the United States."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Wilson of SC to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of June 21.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Collins to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
